definitions.definition: To put an object into a place where it will rest; to fix; to set firm.
examples: Be sure to seat the gasket properly before attaching the cover.

definitions.definition: To provide with a place to sit.
examples: This classroom seats two hundred students.
The waiter seated us and asked what we would like to drink.

definitions.definition: To request or direct one or more persons to sit.
examples: Please seat the audience after the anthem and then introduce the first speaker.

definitions.definition: To recognize the standing of a person or persons by providing them with one or more seats which would allow them to participate fully in a meeting or session.
examples: Only half the delegates from the state were seated at the convention because the state held its primary too early.
You have to be a member to be seated at the meeting. Guests are welcome to sit in the visitors section.

definitions.definition: To cause to occupy a post, site, or situation; to station; to establish; to fix; to settle.
To settle; to plant with inhabitants.
To put a seat or bottom in.

main_definition: ( transitive ) To put an object into a place where it will rest; to fix; to set firm.
secondary_definitions: ( transitive ) To provide with a place to sit.
( transitive ) To request or direct one or more persons to sit.
( transitive , legislature ) To recognize the standing of a person or persons by providing them with one or more seats which would allow them to participate fully in a meeting or session.
( transitive ) To assign the seats of.
( transitive ) To cause to occupy a post, site, or situation; to station; to establish; to fix; to settle.
( obsolete , intransitive ) To rest ; to lie down .
To settle; to plant with inhabitants.
( transitive ) To put a seat or bottom in.
